Award.AwardTitle: CC*IIE Campus Design: Advancing Research at Carleton College via 10Gbps Upgrade to the Northern Lights GigaPOP and Implementation of a Science DMZ

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This project broadly improves Carleton's cyberinfrastructure design and integration to ensure system performance and reliability, including rate and security of data transfer, in support of computational science. Project goals include (1) Upgrading campus Internet2 connection to the Northern Lights GigaPOP to a speed of 10Gbps; (2) Designing and building a prototype Science DMZ to provide immediate support for researchers constrained by the current limitations of the campus building and data infrastructures; (3) Blending the experience gained from the prototype Science DMZ with the ongoing work of the Carleton Science Planning Group to formulate the most effective plan for end-to-end research connectivity, with attention to proposed expansion and remodeling of campus science facilities; (4) Leveraging the knowledge and experience gained by the faculty and staff in this process into the ongoing collaboration efforts to facilitate shared research nationally and internationally. The project's design and implementation is based on best practices developed by successful NSF-funded projects, with particular focus on design of a Science DMZ to meet the needs of researchers at a research-oriented liberal arts college. The design and implementation of the project improves high bandwidth connections accessible to end-users in order to improve network performance and predictability for a wide range of applications. The project addresses specific cyberinfrastructure limitations that impede faculty research with external research partners. Project leaders will present findings regarding design challenges and innovations at national workshops, meetings, and conferences in order to advance small-institution understanding of SDN across wide-area and campus cyberinfrastructure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Carleton College has used the NSF Cyber-Instructure award to create a sustainable infrastructure with sufficient speed and capacity to facilitate the high-end research conducted by the faculty we recruit as a top 10 liberal arts college. A specific objective was to create an environment conducive to the growth in computational research evidenced among incoming STEM faculty and also new hires in the social sciences (e.g. Economics and History) and the intentional growth of research opportunities for our undergraduate students.  Another critical objective was to create more economy of scale by growing our collaboration with St. Olaf. We surpassed the original objectives by also finding fertile ground among the new faculty for sharing of infrastructure and leveraging their start-up and grant funding through creation of a cluster environment built upon the high capacity network made available by this grant.

Three faculty researchers exemplify the range of current and future uses of this new infrastructure. Professor Deborah Gross leverages the increased network bandwidth, Professor Joshua Davis leverages the increased computational power, and Professor Rika Anderson leverages the close proximity of fast storage to fast computational resources.

Professor Gross has been an institutional leader in expanding the opportunities for undergraduate student research. In her lab, student researchers explore very large data sets of airborne particulates, which is complicated by having multiple dimensions across different time series. This infrastructure will allow her students to exchange that data in a database format with international collaborators, which they have been prevented from doing by network latency. The result will be to accelerate their research into the effect of aerosol particles on the environment and human health.

Professor Davis performed large-scale numerical experiments to create models on how the crystalline structures of rocks deform, seeking to achieve exactly a 95% confidence interval on the model. His work may improve future studies of rock deformation and rock magnetism which support greater understanding of the factors at play in the transfer of energy among rocks at earthquake fault lines.

Professor Anderson uses bioinformatic approaches to investigate how marine microorganisms evolve in response to the extreme environment of deep-sea hydrothermal vents. To do so, she is developing techniques to analyze gene sequences that are very computationally intensive. The overarching goal of Professor Anderson's research is researching what these marine microorganisms can teach us about the origin and early evolution of life on our planet.

The first activity of this grant was to bring redundant high-speed connectivity to Northfield in partnership with St. Olaf College. After construction of the foundational 10 Gigabit/sec network infrastructure and the high-speed data transfer server, Information Technology Services (ITS) and the Dean of the College worked with the faculty community to establish a Computational Research User Group to collaboratively manage the development of resources for computational research.

Historically, the College has supported individual faculty research projects as individual efforts, uncoordinated and disconnected, a ?walled garden? serving only one mission, to be used for individual purposes and with no life-cycle management. Now, using grant resources to establish not just a capacious high-speed network, but also storage and computational resource pools, the College is able to offer faculty access to shared environments that represent an efficiently managed resource that can be expanded and developed for various needs while minimizing wasteful duplication of effort and assets. The creation of Service Level Agreements allow the faculty to trust in a shared computational environment that meshes well with Carleton?s sustainability focus. The timing of this project aligned with the construction of a new science complex. The faster network connection and strengthened sense of partnership allowed the College to avoid creating a secondary data center in the new complex -- a significant cost and environmental efficiency.

Additionally, the fact that the resources deployed in this new environment are extensible means that faculty can ?buy-in? with other funds to create the capacity they need in a more cost-effective fashion, allowing greater results for every dollar invested. Furthermore, Carleton intends that the pool of resources will result in better resource utilization, by lowering the entry point and making it easier to use for teaching purposes. An unintended benefit of the shared environment is that junior faculty will be able to get their research started more quickly and can be more thoughtful about how and when to invest their start-up funding most effectively.

Carleton researchers are leveraging this investment in cyber-infrastructure to advance their own research areas and to expand opportunities for undergraduate student research. In a world of exploding amounts of information in every discipline and profession, developing strategies and skills for managing and evaluating that data is of growing importance for all citizens.
